bibl.title: Letter from Adrian Macia to John J. Moran, October 19, 1940

div1.p: Macia writes that Moran may obtain the shack at no cost, or at the least possible cost, after Macia consults with his partners in the brickyard business.

div1.head: Letter from Adrian Macia to John J. Moran, October 19, 1940
div1.opener:
ADRIAN MACIA
INGENIERO CIVIL Y ARQUITECTO
HABANA
October 19, 1940.
Mr. John J. Moran,
Havana.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
With reference to our conversation of a few days ago re-
garding the building used in the famous and happily successful ex-
periments in the investigation into the cause of Yellow Fever in
the year 1900, and in which experiments you, together with your com-
panions subjected yourselves to such heroic risks, I am very pleased
to confirm to you that, although the building does not only belong
to me but also to my partners of the brickyard in which the building
stands today, you will be allowed to obtain the said building, if
possible without any cost to you or, if I am not able to fix it this
way, at the least possible expense.

As I told you, I will be only too glad to contribute as
much as I can (or as much as circumstances will allow me) for this
purpose but am sorry not to be able to give you a more definite
answer just now as I have not yet been able to see my partners in
this property.
With kindest personal regards, I am
